'''''Lactarius pseudomucidus''''' is a [[fungus]] native to the northwestern part of North America. It has a charcoal brown [[Cap (mycology)|cap]], smooth and slimy, about 4–10 cm across, initially flat [[Convex shape|convex]], becoming shallowly depressed. [[Gill (mushroom)|Gills]] are [[decurrent]], with a bluish-gay tinge. [[Stipe (mycology)|Stipe]] is 40–100 mm tall, hollow, brittle. Flesh gray. [[Latex]] is milky white. There is only a slight odor, and the taste slowly becomes acrid. [[Spore print|Spores]] are white in mass, [[ellipsoid]], [[amyloid]], about 8 μm long, with a [[wikt:reticulate|reticulate]] decoration on the surface.<ref>Phillips, Roger. 1981. Mushrooms of North America. Boston: Little & Brown.</ref><ref>Hesler, LR, & AH Smith. 1979. North American species of Lactarius. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press.</ref><ref>Smith, AH. 1975. Field guide to western mushrooms. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press.</ref>
